facts.text: The case is an appeal numbered Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1950 in the Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1950. Appeal from the judgment and order dated 29th June,

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated 29th June 1950 of the High Court of Judicature at Simla by Weston J. and Khosla J. in Criminal Appeal No. 432 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated 29th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Simla  Weston J. and Khosla J.  in Criminal Appeal No. 432 of 1949 arising out of a judgment

facts.text: The High Court appeal arose from judgment dated 5th August 1949 of the Additional Sessions Judge, Amritsar, in Sessions Trial No. 7 of 1949 and Case No. 8 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of a judgment dated 5th August, 1949, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Amritsar, in Ses- sions Trial No. 7 of 1949 and Case No. 8 of 1949. Jai Gopal Sethi  R. L. Kohli, with him  for the appel- lants.

facts.text: Three appellants were tried by Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar, found guilty of murdering Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh, sentenced to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZL ALl J. --The three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of having murdered two persons named Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab upheld conviction and sentence of the three appellants and granted certificate under article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Punjab upheld their conviction and sentence and granted them a certificate under article 134 1  c of the Constitution that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: On the evening of 16th December 1948, a little before sunset, Achhar Singh went to the house of Inder Singh in village Dalam for getting paddy husked.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case may be briefly stated as follows. On the evening of 16th December, 1948, a little before sunset, Achhar Singh, one of the murdered persons, went to the house of one Inder Singh in village Dalam for getting paddy husked.

facts.text: Darshan Singh, brother of Achhar Singh, came from Amritsar to Dalam on the evening of 16th December 1948 and went to Inder Singh's house upon learning Achhar was there.

anchor.surface_text: Achhar Singhs brother, Darshan Singh, who was working as a driver at Amritsar, came to Dalam from Amritsar the same evening, and, on learning to know from his father that Achhar Singh had gone to Inder Singhs house, he also went there.

facts.text: While Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh were returning home, they were attacked by the three appellants and two relatives in a lane adjoining Inder Singh's house.

anchor.surface_text: while the two brothers were returning home, they were attacked by the three appellants and two of their relatives in a lane adjoining Inder Singhs house. The five assailants, who were armed with deadly weapons, in- flicted a number of injuries on the two victims,

facts.text: The five assailants inflicted injuries on Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh using deadly weapons, resulting in their death at the spot.

anchor.surface_text: The five assailants, who were armed with deadly weapons, in- flicted a number of injuries on the two victims, as a result of which they died then and there. After the murder, the appellants and their companions tied the two dead bodies in two kheses  wrappers

facts.text: After the murder, appellants and companions tied the dead bodies in two kheses (wrappers) and took them to village Saleempura.

anchor.surface_text: After the murder, the appellants and their companions tied the two dead bodies in two kheses  wrappers  and took them to village Saleempura where two other persons, named Ajaib Singh and Banta Singh, joined them,

facts.text: At Saleempura, Ajaib Singh and Banta Singh joined, dead bodies were dismembered and thrown into Sakinala stream about five miles from Dalam.

anchor.surface_text: and took them to village Saleempura where two other persons, named Ajaib Singh and Banta Singh, joined them, and the dead bodies after being dismembered were thrown into a stream known as Sakinala at a place about five miles from village Dalam.

facts.text: Bela Singh, father of deceased, witnessed the occurrence but left village next morning two hours before sunrise and lodged first information report at 10 A.M. at nearest police station.

anchor.surface_text: Bela Singh, father of the deceased persons, who was one of the persons who claims to have witnessed the occurrence, did not leave the village at night on account of fear, but he started about two hours before sunrise on the next morning and lodged the first information report at 10 A.M. at the nearest police station.

facts.text: Police officer arrived in Dalam shortly after FIR, investigation led to charge-sheet against seven persons including present appellants.

anchor.surface_text: A police officer arrived in village Dalam shortly after- wards, and after investigation a charge-sheet was submitted against seven persons including the present appellants. At the trial, five of the accused were charged with offences under section 302 read with section 149

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellants and two others under section 302/149 IPC to life transportation, Ajaib Singh under 201/149 to 3 years RI, acquitted Banta Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who tried the accused, convicted the appellants and two other persons under section 302 read with section 149 of the Penal Code and sentenced them to transportation for life, and convicted Ajaib Singh under section 201 read with section 149 and sentenced him to three years R.I. Bantu Singh, accused, was acquitted.

facts.text: Punjab High Court on appeal upheld conviction of present appellants, acquitted remaining three persons.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Punjab High Court upheld the conviction of the present appellants and acquitted the remaining three persons. Before proceeding to discuss the evidence in the case, it is necessary to refer to what has been.

facts.text: In June 1947, Natha Singh, father of third appellant Swaran Singh, was murdered.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to discuss the evidence in the case, it is necessary to refer to what has been. described as the motive for the murder. It appears that in June, 1947, Natha Singh, father of the third appellant, Swaran Singh, was murdered,

facts.text: Darshan Singh, Achhar Singh, and Sulakhan Singh were charged with murder of Natha Singh; Darshan acquitted, Achhar sentenced to 1.5 years RI, Sulakhan to 7 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: and Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh, the two mur- dered persons in the case before us, and their third broth- er, Sulakhan Singh, were charged with the murder of that person. As a result of the trial, Darshan Singh was acquit- ted and Achhar Singh was sentenced to 11/2 years R.I., while Sulakhan Singh was sentenced to 7 years R.I.

facts.text: Achhar Singh was released on bail by appellate court and was at large at the time of the present occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Sessions Judge in that case was delivered shortly before the date of the present occurrence, and it is common ground that Achhar Singh had been released on bail by the appellate court and was at large at that time.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants conceded that prior facts constituted strong motive for the murder.

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us by the learned counsel for the appellants that the facts stated above constituted a strong motive for the murder, but he also contended that they constituted an equally strong motive for the appellants being falsely implicated

facts.text: Second appellant Massa Singh arrested on 18th December 1948 wearing pyjama stained with human blood.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstantial evidence in the case, on which the High Court has relied, may be briefly summarised as follows -- The second appellant, Massa Singh, who was arrested on the 18th December, 1948, was wearing a pyjama stained with human blood.

facts.text: Third appellant Swaran Singh arrested on 18th December 1948, on 19th December took police to locked haveli where two blood-stained kheses wrappers recovered.

anchor.surface_text: The third appellant, Swaran Singh, who was arrested on the 18th December, 1948, took the police on the 19th December to his haveli which was locked, and, on opening it two kheses  wrappers  which were stained with human blood were recovered.

facts.text: Swaran Singh pointed out spot on way to Sakinala where bodies placed temporarily, blood-stained earth scrapped by police.

anchor.surface_text: Swaran Singh pointed out a spot on the way to Saki- nala, where the two dead bodies were placed for a short time while they were being taken to Sakinala, and the police scrapped blood-stained earth from that spot.

facts.text: Swaran Singh led police to bank of Sakinala and pointed out trunk of Darshan Singh's body.

anchor.surface_text: He also led the police to the bank of Sakinala and pointed out the trunk of the body of Darshan Singh which was lying in the nala. Lachhman Singh, who was arrested on the 28th Decem- ber, 1948, pointed out a dilapidated khola near Sakinala

facts.text: Lachhman Singh arrested on 28th December 1948, pointed out dilapidated khola near Sakinala where 3 spears, one kirpan and a datar stained with human blood recovered.

anchor.surface_text: Lachhman Singh, who was arrested on the 28th Decem- ber, 1948, pointed out a dilapidated khola near Sakinala where 3 spears, one kirpan and a datar, all stained with human blood, were recovered. The learned Sessions Judge, who heard the evidence,

facts.text: Prosecution eye-witnesses: Bela Singh (father), Inder Singh and wife Mst. Taro, Gurcharan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The direct evidence consists of the testimony of four eye-witnesses, namely, Bela Singh, father of the deceased, who claims to have gone to the scene of occurrence on hearing an outcry and to have witnessed the murderous assault on his sons Inder Singh and his wife, Mst. Taro,

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 21, 1952 by Fazl Ali J.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal Singh for the State. 1952. March 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZL ALl J. --The three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of having murdered two persons named Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh
certificate under article 134 1 c of the Constitution that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court. Hence this appeal.

arguments.claim: The prior enmity constituted an equally strong motive for the appellants being falsely implicated

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us by the learned counsel for the appellants that the facts stated above constituted a strong motive for the murder, but he also contended that they constituted an equally strong motive for the appellants being falsely implicated in case the murder was committed, as was suggested by him, in circumstances under which the murderers could not be seen or identified.

arguments.claim: It would be proper not to rely upon the oral evidence implicating particular accused unless there is some circumstantial evidence to support it

arguments.claim: The blood-stained pyjama recovered from Massa Singh does not corroborate due to unclear extent of stains and improbability of wearing it post-crime

anchor.surface_text: The comment of the learned counsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from Massa Singh was, firstly, that it was not possible to gather from the evidence the extent of the blood stains, and secondly that it would be highly improbable that this accused person would be so reckless as to continue to wear a blood stained pyjama after having perpetrated the crime.

arguments.claim: Scope of Supreme Court criminal appeal is limited after sifting by trial court and High Court; no reassessment of evidence or facts

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this Court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court, it seems to us that the question involved in the present appeal is a short and simple one.

arguments.claim: Corroboration required for oral evidence is not accomplice-level but circumstances lending assurance that accused concerned in murder

anchor.surface_text: According to our reading of the judgment of the High Court...the corroboration which the learned judges required...was not that kind of corroboration which one requires in the case of the evidence of an approver or an accomplice, but corroboration by some circumstances which would lend assurance to the evidence before them

arguments.claim: Eyewitness evidence is consistent, reliable, and establishes guilt of five accused, further proved by recoveries

anchor.surface_text: This evidence was so consistent, so reliable, and of such nature that in my opinion it is definitely established that the five accused...are proved to have actually murdered both Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh. This fact is further proved from subsequent events as deposed by P.W. 8 Bahadur Singh...

holdings.text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court prescribed standard of circumstantial corroboration for oral evidence as matter of prudence; Supreme Court applies same standard and finds specific circumstantial links (pyjama, khesas, pointings) corroborate identification of each appellant.

holdings.text: This criticism has been considered by the courts below, and it does not appear to us to be of such a nature as to affect the conclusion arrived at by them.

anchor.surface_text: This criticism has been considered by the courts below, and it does not appear to us to be of such a nature as to affect the conclusion arrived at by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenges to blood extent and improbability of wearing stained pyjama rejected as already considered below and not undermining lower courts' findings.

holdings.text: It is sufficient to say that it is not the function of this Court to reassess evidence and an argument on a point of fact which did not prevail with the courts below cannot avail the appellants in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to say that it is not the function of this Court to reassess evidence and an argument on a point of fact which did not prevail with the courts below cannot avail the appellants in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court's scope in criminal appeals limited to not re-appreciating facts or evidence sifted by trial and High Court; police investigation suspicions do not warrant interference.

holdings.text: For the purpose of this appeal, however, it is sufficient to state that even if the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants which apparently found favour with the High Court, is correct, the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh cannot be ruled out of consideration.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal, however, it is sufficient to state that even if the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants which apparently found favour with the High Court, is correct, the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh cannot be ruled out of consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming strict rule excluding joint information under S.27 requires first informant identifiable, Swaran Singh's was initial pointing leading to specific discoveries (haveli khesas, spot, trunk).

holdings.text: The finding of the doctor therefore does not necessarily affect the prosecution case as to the time of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the doctor therefore does not necessarily affect the prosecution case as to the time of occurrence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partially digested rice affected by multiple digestion factors; no data on last meal timing or contents; High Court considered, does not contradict eyewitness timing.

holdings.text: as at present advised we are inclined to think that some of the cases relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellants have perhaps gone farther than is warranted by the language of section 27, and it may be that on a suitable occasion in future those cases may have to be reviewed.

anchor.surface_text: as at present advised we are inclined to think that some of the cases relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellants have perhaps gone farther than is warranted by the language of section 27, and it may be that on a suitable occasion in future those cases may have to be reviewed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter suggestion that prior strict interpretations limiting S.27 to first informant in joint statements may exceed statutory language; possible future review.

holdings.text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this Court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this Court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court follows its precedents limiting interference in criminal appeals post lower court scrutiny to compelling reasons only.
